message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis. The Monospot test is a rapid diagnostic test for infectious mononucleosis, and is the most likely test to diagnose the patient's condition. Throat culture and urine culture are not specific to infectious mononucleosis, and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) may not accurately diagnose the condition at this stage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, and the Monospot test is the most likely test to diagnose it. Throat culture is useful for diagnosing bacterial infections, urine culture for urinary tract infections, and Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for various viral infections like HIV or hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, which can be diagnosed with the Monospot test. Throat culture and urine culture are not specific for this condition, and while enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay can detect specific antibodies, the Monospot test is more commonly used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis (also known as mono or the kissing disease), and the Monospot test is used to diagnose it. Throat culture is used to diagnose strep throat, which presents differently than mono. Urine culture is used to diagnose urinary tract infections. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a general term for a test that uses antibodies and color change to detect the presence of a substance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam suggest infectious mononucleosis, which can be confirmed with the Monospot test. Throat culture can diagnose bacterial infections, but infectious mononucleosis is caused by a virus. Urine culture is not relevant in this case. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) can also diagnose infectious mononucleosis, but the Monospot test is more commonly used.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. The Monospot test is the most commonly used test for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. Throat culture and urine culture are not likely to be useful in diagnosing this condition, and an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) may not be as sensitive as the Monospot test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, which would be confirmed by a positive Monospot test. Throat and urine cultures would not be specific for this condition. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) can be used to confirm the presence of antibodies against the Epstein-Barr virus, which causes infectious mononucleosis, but the Monospot test is more commonly used for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis. The Monospot test is the most specific test for infectious mononucleosis. Throat culture and urine culture are unlikely to provide a diagnosis while ELISA may show false-positive results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest infectious mononucleosis, and the Monospot test is the most specific and sensitive test for diagnosing it. Throat culture and urine culture would not be helpful. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay can be used to confirm the diagnosis but is less specific and sensitive than the Monospot test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are suggestive of infectious mononucleosis, and the most likely test to diagnose this condition is the monospot test, which detects heterophile antibodies in the blood. Throat culture and urine culture are not specific for mononucleosis, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is used for a variety of conditions and is not specific for mononucleosis.
